titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Thursday

My Son, went to Boston, and returned to dine— After dinner Mr Ayer a Carpenter whom he has employed for building his house, came from Boston, and examined the ground— William Spear came, and I went with him to Harvey Field’s and with him to the Verchild pasture— There Mr Field, explained to me his wishes and made his proposals, which were to purchase the wood standing upon it, and to clear up about five Acres of it for a plantation of mulberry trees— He supposes the land clearing may cost 100 dollars, and will undertake it for that, and then offers 6 dollars a year additional rent for the land so cleared, if I should not choose to plant mulberry trees. We then went to the ground which he and Adam Curtis purchased of James Brackett; which they laid out in house lots, upon which three houses are already built, and he is building a fourth— He proposes to me, to continue the road which they have opened, to pay fifty dollars to them for the benefit that I shall derive from their road, and from a bridge which they are building over the Country road, to drain the winter’s water from the grounds round their new houses; and he offers to contract to build for me four houses for 600 dollars each, and which he warrants will rent for 48 dollars a year each; and he advises me to open another cross road on the West-side of Samuel Curtis’s house lot, and a road to meet it from the County road— All these improvements he thinks will raise the value of my estate far more than they will cost— I agreed to name two persons to appraise the wood; and was inclined to agree to have the five acres cleared, and planted with white mulberry trees or seed— Of the other proposals that I should give lands and money to open new roads, and build houses upon speculation, I desired time for consideration— After Spear had taken me home in his waggon, I walked over the hill, and saw the lot staked out for Charles’s house— And I went to the granite ledge opened by Colburn, upon
the hill opposite my house, and saw the breaches already made by his workmen upon the rock— It was dark when I returned and found my family at tea. Joseph H Adams was here, but went home immediately afterwards— In my garde, nursery and seminary observations on this first day of the month, I find my tallest Philadelphia maple, and the shoot from the Wollaston Apple-bud each 44 inches long.— The maple is taller than a transplanted red maple; plucked from my lower meadow, and set out in the garden in 1831. October; and yet that is flourishing— To obey my Gardener transplanted my seedling Strawberry from Potto the Netarine Strawberry bed in the garden— I filled the Pot with fresh Earth, and sowed in it 30 seed of the Apples from the Dwarf tree; just now ripe— I have in the cleared hazel bed 25 Seedling peach-trees and 25 hickory walnuts of the present year. Of Apples, Pears Cherry ash, and elm I take no account— My progress in the Eulogy is slow
2. IV Friday.

Mr Charles Foster with his three Sisters, were here on a visit this afternoon— Mary’s health has improved, though yet infirm— Mrs Quincy junr and Mrs Miller were here with a special invitation to me to attend the centennial celebration at Cambridge next Thursday— John P. De Wint junr made also a short visit here— Mr William Spear came at four O’Clock this afternoon, and I went with him and my Son Charles over the hill to the quarry where Colburn’s men are working, and thence withDutton to the Southeast corner of the lot where Dutton supposes there is a suitable ledge to be wrought— We examined the ground and my Son for me agreed to give him a lease for five years similar to that of Colburn with a slight advance upon the price of the stone— It was about Sunset when I returned home— Mary and Charles’s wife were gone to take tea, at Mrs Ann Adams’s, and on a visit to Mrs Lunt— Charles went for them, but came soon home with them, unwell with a severe headache— My Plantation and my Eulogy; my two Granddaughters and my Diary divide and consume my time. I looked this day into Mr Wirt’s Life of Patrick Henry, to see his account of the debates in the Virginia Convention upon the Constitution of the United-States, and of Henry’s opinion and conduct on the occasion of the alien and Sedition Laws— It seems difficult to reconcile them together— His opposition to the Constitution was founded perhaps on the peculiarity of his situation.— His opinions then were in the highest tone of republican doctrine, and his aversion to the consolidation of the union deeply rooted— This makes his approbation of the Alien and Sedition Laws the more extraordinary— But in truth the opposition to those Laws was merely factious— The main argument of Mr Madison’s report against the alien Law was that it applied to alien friends, when such measures should be applied only to alien enemies— But there was a fallacy in it.— The foreign emissaries against whom the alien act was pointed were in no wise friends of this Country— They were chiefly Frenchmen— Jefferson in his correspondence says its principal object was Volney— The relative situation
of the United States and France, at that time not a state of amity, but of hostility, though not of declared war— It was such that measures of defence against French secret emissaries were more necessary than they would have been in avowed and open War— The Sedition act was an ineffectual attempt to extinguish the fire of defamation—but it operated like oil upon the flame. Patrick Henry was elected a member of the Legislature of Virginia in 1799. but he died in June of that year, and before their meeting.
3. V. Saturday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— John P. De Wint junr was here this forenoon— Mr Beale came this Evening to remind me that the annual meeting and dinner at Squantum of the proprietors of the Neponset Bridge would be next Tuesday, at one or two O’Clock— This being the Anniversary of the signature at Paris of the definitive Treaty of Peace which recognized and consummated the Independence of the United States of America, and also of my Son Charles’s Marriage, I gave him the Seal which by my father’s direction, I had engraved at London, in 1815. with his device of the Deer, the Pine tree and the Fish, surrounded by the thirteen Stars, by which in 1783. he commemorated the rights of the Fisheries and of the boundary, secured by the Treaty of Peace with Great-Britain— My father gave the original Seal to my late dear and lamented son John—and it remains one of the relics left by him— It has on the other side of the stone the Adams arms, but has not the motto “Piscemur, Venemur ut olim.”— He gave this which is a single Seal and has the motto, to me; and I have given it to Charles, with the request that he would at his own time give it to his Son Charles Francis, if by the blessing of Providence he should live and prove worthy of his great Grandfather who invented the Seal, and of whose life it commemorates a most eventful period— I had already on the 27th of October 1833. committed in trust to Charles, for the remainder of my life, the Lion created Seal at arms of the Boylston family, with which my father sealed the Treaties of 30. November 1782 and 1783. to be retained as his property after my decease, and ultimately to be given to his Son—John Quincy, if worthy of it, or to any other Son that he might have— I received this day a Letter from Mr Armstrong the Mayor of Boston, a Letter requesting me to fix a day for the delivery of the Eulogy upon Mr Madison, and proposing Friday the 16th. of this Month—but I fear I shall not then be ready; having barely yet got through with the discussion of the Alien and Sedition Laws— I am endeavouring once more to ascertain the particular Apples and Pears from which the Seeds that I sow vegetate— I emptied Pot 12. in which on the 9th of November last I had sown one whole Button garden Pear, 8 Seeds and 10. Office-Apple Seeds— Not one of them has come up— Of the whole pear, nothing but a fragment of the skin remains and the core with the seeds in it all dried up— I sowed the seeds of a small white pippin between the two peach trees in the seminary, and between two stakes to mark where they are— I transplanted also four seedling elms, of this year growing too close to a fifth and to each other— I found a pignut hickory in the row between the Summer house cellar and the road, scarcely perceptible and just out of the ground— This is the cause of the difficulty of raising the walnut— It comes up so late in the Season, that the stem has not time to harden before it is nipped by the frost— I took from a black walnut leaf, two worms about half ground of the kind that I have found occasionally in clusters on the leaves of the black oak, voracious villains with a bright red head and just after the neck a hump with a shell upon it of the same red colour, and a short thick black hair like the bristle issuing from its centre; four or five other such hairs about its neck, and the rest of the body of a dun brown colour, thinly covered with brown downy hair— I had already taken two
clusters of the same kind of worm, not half so much grown from the same black walnut—the growth of which they have arrested for the Season— I took a yellow caterpillar worm also, from a leaf of the best grown seedling white Ash of this Season that I had— The leaf was half consumed and the growth of the plant arrested for this year— My Son’s child John Quincy was taken quite unwell this Evening with symptoms of fever— He had got a hurt by striking his head against the edge of a door.
4. IV. Sunday.

My grandson John Quincy was quite ill last Night, and had a fever all this day— Dr Woodward was sent for and directed medicines to be administered to him— Mr Lunt preached this morning, from 2. Peter 1.4. “Whereby are given unto us exceeding great and precious promises; that by these ye might be partakers of the divine nature, having escaped the corruption that is in the world through lust.” An exposition of the inestimable privilege, and the irreversible duty of Christians to be partakers of the divine nature, and of the properties in which that consists.— In the afternoon Mr. Lunt’s discourse was from Galatians 1.23. [“]But they had heard only that he which persecuted us in times past, now preacheth the faith, which once he destroyed. 24. And they glorified God in me.” An argument for Christianity from the conversion of St. Paul—ingenious and forcible, but not original— Charles occupied his pew N. 61. which I have given him— I read the fragments of the 12th. and 13th. Sermons of Saurin’s 8th. Volume—on the dispositions suitable for attendance on Public worship— Pages 441 and 442. missing with the beginning of Sermon 12. and the part of Sermon 13 in the book, being apparently less than half the discourse— I regret the mutilation of them all, and still more my own incapacity to profit by what is profitable— The author divides his theme into dispositions suitable for attendance 1. on preaching. 2. on prayer 3. on Self improvement, or vows. It would seem as if in his age and time, it was usual for Christians by way of improvement, at the close of public worship, to bind themselves tacitly by vows, or engage their consciences to do some particular thing— His observations upon this practice, which he rather discourages, are sensible and instructive— But at this time and in this country I believe no such practice exists— Coll. Quincy and Mr Thomas Davis were here this Evening. They both enquired with some solicitude, if I should attend at the centennial celebration at Cambridge next Thursday— I thought I should not— I should be glad to hear President Quincy’s discourse; but there is to be a public dinner, at which it is expected there will be 1500 persons present, and to which a political party complexion has been given. Harrison Gray Otis, is to preside at the dinner.
5. IV:15. Monday

Charles went into Boston, and returned to dine. Joseph H. Adams came out from Boston with him and dined with us Josiah Adams junr. came, and I gave him a check on the Bank for 300 dollars on account of his work for me at Mount Wollaston— Samuel Clough was one of the Stone-Cutters here, and on the first of March last crippled himself for life by an unlucky blast of gunpowder— He has a wife and children and needs assistance. Such cases are becoming frequent in the Quarires— Winkley came here with five dollars and a half the sum he has to pay for about four Months work upon his ledge
to the 22d. of May— He said he had been to New-York, and engaged a company who wanted to purchase the ledge— I told him I had promised not to dispose of it for the rest of this month, but should then be ready and willing to sell to him; but I referred him to my Son Charles for agreement upon terms— The weather changed and there was some rain— I have again an inflammation coming in my right eye, and am about to be again disabled for writing.
6. IV. Tuesday.
Fahrenheit 45.— Squantum dinner party—

The inflammation of my right eye increases and is painful. It totally discomposes my writing and reading. Mr E. Price Greenleaf came this morning, and visited my Cherry trees which he has budded this year. I have suffered the time for budding Apple trees this Summer to escape— It should be done within ten days of the 15th. of August.— I began sowing dwarf-Apple-seeds and dried white currants in a front row along the Seminary bed adjourning the Northern fence; which I have had widened this Summer for the purpose of sowing this front row. Mr E. P. Greenleaf came at Noon, and I walked with him and Charles to Squantum in one hour and 18 minutes, with a strong cold Northeast wind blowing directly in our face, which delayed us 2 minutes a mile— The distance is four miles and one furlong— At the Meeting of the Proprietors of the Bridge, Thomas Greenleaf was re-elected Clerk, George W. Beale Treasurer, and the Directors of the last year. A vote was passed to hold in future the annual Meeting of the Proprietors on the first Tuesday of July instead of September, a change not agreeable to me, but which I did not oppose.— For six or seven years past the day has always been either foul, or as it was this day, wintry cold. Mr Wales and Mr Edward Miller desired the change, and the rest assented to it. Mr Daniel Greenleaf and Captain Josiah Bass attended the Meeting. Mr P. Whitney and Mr Lunt, Captain Quincy, and Mr Appleton Joseph H. Adams and George W. Beale were at the dinner— We had Chowder, fried fish, and fruit, but the inflammation of my eye dictated abstinence to me, which I observed— I had ordered my Carriage at 5. O’Clock, but the party broke up sooner— I walked part of the way with Mr E. P. Greenleaf home, and met my Carriage on the way. Charles rode home with Mr Thomas Greenleaf— I found Louisa C. Smith and Elizabeth C. Adams at our house, where they took tea— Joseph H. Adams came to escort them home— I suffered pain from the inflammation of my eye and made a short evening— Hot [symbols]
7. V. Wednesday.

The inflammation of my eye still painful and increasing disables me for all the occupations of duty and of pleasure which give wings to time, excepting the busy idleness of my Garden. I sowed in Pot 6. one Green gage Plum stone 2. Horse Plum stones and 9 Seeds from a large and fine flavoured red Apple which I brought yesterday from Squantum— My curiosity to trace the plant to its identical seed, increases with its disappointments; and the best chance that I have for gratifying it is by transplanting them, to the Garden, after raising them in numbered Pots, entering yearly upon my record the seed sown, and the plant proceeding from it, a system which after ten years of experience, I have not yet brought to practical maturity— The disappointment is that many of the seeds the sowing of which I most carefully mark never come up, and that those of which I take little note when sown do come up, and live and grow. I planted also in the Seminary one Green Gage Plum stone, between four stakes, though I must doubt whether any of the Green gage stones that I have sown have ever come up— Of all the experiments that I
I have made, I find the Plum the most difficult to raise— Mr Seawell Jones of North-Carolina came and introduced his friend Mr Manly of that State.— The newspapers have announced him as a candidate for the Senate of the United States; I mentioned the report to him; but he said his name had been brought forward by the opposition, (to the re-election of Mr Mangum[)]— But he was too young for a Senator— He said he had heard that Governor Everett was to preside at the centennial dinner at Cambridge, next Thursday.— Mr Harrison Gray Otis being prevented from attending by the sudden death of his wife last Sunday morning— Dr Stephen Thayer of Braintree was here and introduced to me his friend Mr Lyde of Boston— He came to invite me to deliver the introductory Lecture for the second Lyceum at that City— Mr Webster is to improvisate the introductory for the first Lyceum; that for which I have already declined to discourse I declined also in this case though Mr Lyde was earnest almost to importunity in his solicitations, and though I felt much flattered by the perseverance of his intreaties William Spear came and told me that he and Noah Curtis had appraised the wood on the Atherton and Verchild Pasture at 475 dollars, reserving 16. Apple trees which they thought worth preserving.— I desired to him to inform Harvey Field of this appraisement, and to tell him that he might take off the wood at that price— Mr Spear recommended to me also to sell off the wood this winter from the Quincy woodlot, and I promised to go with him and look at it about the beginning of next Month— Mr Benjn L. Dutton came this afternoon, and I executed with him the lease for a ledge of granite rock bordering upon the land of Isaac Bass, for five years— The Lease was drawn, and the terms agreed upon with Dutton by Charles.— Towards Evening the inflammation of my eye partially subsided— Charles red in an hour and twenty minutes about one third part of what I have written for the Eulogy of James Madison. Hot [symbols]
8. IV. Thursday.— Fahrenheit 51.— Harvard University Centennial.

The inflammation of my eye so far subsided that I resumed my writing, though with an anxious fear that I shall not be long allowed to continue it— Nor could I devote to writing more than a small portion of the day— Charles went to Boston, and attended at the delivery of the centennial address by President Quincy, but returned home to dinner— My forenoon was spent chiefly in my garden, and the afternoon in strolling over the Hill, to the ledge opened by Colburn and to that contracted for by Benjamin L. Dutton— The Season for sowing seeds and planting Stones of fruit trees has come and I renew my attempts to sow varieties and to preserve the connection between the seed and the plant— I gathered 4 Rosebud Apples and two Early wild pears—and one small red wedge wild Apple for seed. I incline to the opinion that of the Apple, Pear, Plum and Cherry, wilding seed is the best especially for Stocks, and the extreme difference in the rapidity of growth from seeds of the same kind of fruit has sharpened my curiosity while it mortifies me at my ineffective devices to preserve the genealogy between the seed and the plant— I gathered also two or three wild button pears, but they do not ripen till the last of October— Dutton has not yet begun upon his ledge— Colburn is industriously working upon his and well satisfied with it— My grand child Louisa-Catherine planted two horse plum stones in her plat— I believe that not one of the Plum stones that I received from Mr Cruft has ever come up— About one horse plum stone of two hundred planted comes up; but most of them soon die, and those that live grow so slow, and are so weakly, that I fear they will never come to any thing.— I found two of the worst worms on elm leaves, and put them under the quart Tumbler
9. IV:15. Friday

I was [symbols] restored to the power of writing and reading, but much interrupted by visitors throughout this day. Mr Thomas Adams junr the Collector came, and I gave him a check on the Bank for my parish-tax— Mr Brooks the Minister of Hingham called on his return from Medford, after the centennial at Cambridge, yesterday, of which he gave me a particular account, and with which he was beyond measure delighted— Governor Everett presided and made a very acceptable speech at the dinner— President Quincy’s discourse was very eloquent—chiefly historical, and about two hours long. Mary, and Charles’s wife dined at Mrs: Ann Adams’s. My wife went there after dinner to take tea, and I walked there with Charles at the dusk of Evening. I had a long afternoon visit from Mr W B. Calhoun, and Mr Briggs, our two Western Members of Congress, both of whom were at the centennial yesterday, and were much pleased with the performances. Briggs shewed me a Latin song to the tune of yankee-doodle which was not sung— There was another Latin song sung; and Latin toasts, and one toast in greek given by Alden Bradford— We had much conversation; but very little of politics as there is scarcely any thing to talk about. They took tea here and went away about Sunset— Briggs returns home to-morrow. Calhoun is to be in and about Boston eight or ten days longer— John Foster a son of the late Phineas Foster came here with Joseph H. Adams, and a Letter from Isaac Hull Adams at New-York. His pocket-book was stolen from him in the Steamboat, and in it was my note to him for three thousand dollars, payable next May— He writes that it was not endorsed, but he is apprehensive that an endorsement on it may be forged and that it may then be negotiated, and Money then fraudulently raised upon it— Hull desired that if I was willing the note might be advertised as stolen; to which I told Mr John Foster that I should make no objection— At Mrs. Adams’s we found her Sister Mrs Phineas Foster, with her daughter Fanny, and Mr and Mrs Boyd of Portland, Maine— She was formerly Susan Harrod— The weather had been all day at high Summer heat; but there came up in the Evening a warm shower, with which Charles and I were besprinkled as we walked home, in pitch darkness— Mrs Foster with her daughter and Mrs Boyd, concluded to stop for the Night at Mrs Adams’s— Mr Boyd and John Foster attempted to return to Boston in a Chaise—lost their way, and were obliged to come back, for the remainder of the Night, also at Mrs. Adams’s.
10. IV.15 Saturday.

Mary’s birth day. 30 and her daughter’s Georgiana Frances. 6. Charles went in to Boston and returned to dine— Mr and Mrs Lunt, Mrs. Ann Adams and her daughter Elizabeth C. and her Son Joseph. He dined also with us, and Louisa C. Smith— Mrs Adams and her Son Joseph immediately after dinner left us and went to Medford to see Mrs. John Angier who is much indisposed— Mr and Mrs Lunt went away immediately after tea, and Louisa C. Smith and Elizabeth C. Adams before 9 in the Evening There was a warm rain last Night, and then a dull November day, and this Evening a very little rain more—scarcely enough to lay the dust for one day— The whole Summer has been so cold and dry, that there has been none such since 1816. and that was not so cold. The wheat crops have failed at the South and the Harvest of Indian Corn is failing here, so that we are seriously threatened with a severe scarcity.— The inflammation has receded from my right eye, but I wrote very little, but visited my garden and inspected my
plantations— The borer worm is destroying the old St. Michael Pear tree South of the Summer house cellar— I discovered yesterday a large handful of Sawdust on the ground at the root of the tree— I swept it away, and this day there was half a handful more in its place— I amputated two of three stems of an English white Oak there adjoining the road—and took a cluster of palmer worms from a young transplanted elm in the Seminary—
11. IV:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr George Putnam of Roxbury, the Successor of the late Dr. Porter— The morning Sermon was from Luke 16.10— “He that is faithful in that which is least, is faithful also in much:”— An excellent practical discourse, exhorting to the constant and punctual discharge of small duties—considering the text itself as commanding them, by placing them in parallel with greater things— The afternoon text was from 1. John 4.16. “God is love: and he that dwelleth in love, dwelleth in God, and God in him.” The favourite system of preaching of almost all the young men from the theological school at Cambridge is the cultivation of the benevolent affections— Perhaps this is the most useful end of preaching; and its tendency to civilize and mollify the manners of man is obvious—“emollit mores, nec sinit esse feros.” but it forms a manner somewhat dry and apt to become tedious by uniformity.— These discourses are all didactic— Few of them are logical—fewer still imaginative; and very seldom learned; or even historical— Mr Putnam dined with us, and is a person of modest deportment and pleasant conversation— Louisa C. Smith and Elizabeth C. Adams also dined with us— Mary attended at the morning service; but was afterwards unwell and took to her bed.— I read the 14th and last Sermon of the 8th. volume of Saurin; on the insufficiency of external worship— His text is from Isaiah 66.3—and the discourse is well adapted to the text— He gives as is usual with him two explanations of the meaning of the prophet in this passage, and remarks that the Mosaic Law was filled with ceremonials to excess, because it was necessary to wean the People from Egyptian idolatries— But that the prophets in the time of the Captivity all press the superior efficacy of moral principles to ritual observances, and that the ceremonial part of the Law was wholly discarded by Jesus Christ. He alludes to the French Protestant refugees as having been exceedingly attached to their forms of worship, and contrasts their afflictions under the necessity of renouncing their country to preserve their protestant faith, with the happiness of the Hollanders whom he addresses and who enjoyed the freedom of Conscience without molestation.
12. V. Monday.

William Spear and Harvey Field were here this morning and I agreed that Mr Field should take off the wood standing upon the Atherton and Verchild pastures, with the strip bordering upon the Penn’s Valley Brook for four hundred and seventy-five dollars; one fourth is to be paid on the 1st. of November, and the remainder without interest on the first of May next; all the wood to be taken off by the first of April— I agreed also to allow him 100 dollars to clear up five Acres, of ground to put in a condition for the planting of white mulberry seeds or trees— I am to draw up an agreement in writing for the purpose and he is to go to work immediately. Sixteen Apple trees upon the place, and not to be cut down— The other project of Mr Field, that he should build four houses for me, I told him I could not agree to for want of the means— Mr Nathaniel Curtis was afterwards here, with plans of an Estate
near Faneuil Hall Market, in Boston, which belonged to the late Mr Boylston, and which Mr Curtis thinks it will be advisable to sell— There are two lots containing about 7500 feet in all, and they are wanted with other Estates bordering on them for a Custom House— They have been appraised by Mr E. H. Robbins, for something over forty-three thousand dollars, at which price Mr Curtis proposes to sell them. I concurred in the opinion, but thought it might be proper to fix it at the round some of 45000 dollars— The other plan was of Lands in Charlestown, which we are to exchange, lot for lot, foot for foot upwards of 3600 feet, with Ebenezer Breed and others Trustees for a company— Mr. Curtis had two drafts of Deeds, one from Breed to us as Trustees of the Estate of Mr Boylston, and the other from us to Breed; but we found upon examination that there must be alterations made to both of them, and they were put into my Son Charles’s hands to draft the deeds for execution— I went and made a deposit at the Quincy Stone Bank, and then walked over the Hill to Colburn and Dutton’s ledges— Dutton has not yet begun upon his, but it seems that Colburn and he are to work the two jointly— I examined most of the apple and about half a dozen pear trees, with a view to try the seeds of the best of them. None of them are ripe, and they are all small— I gathered samples of three Apples finely flavoured mild acid and one of them curiously shaped—wedge like and looking like a small beet— I call it the red wedge wilding; but it will not be ripe within six weeks from this time— The other two I call the rose-bud, and the rock ruby, from their colours, and from the position of the last near an enormous rock in the Cranch lot— The Pears I call the crack the early wilding and the button— I proposed if possible to sow seeds of them all, with such care as to know if any of them come up, from what seeds they come, for I suspect that the breed of fruit trees, is according to their nature, as procreative of virtues and vices as the pedigree of horses. In pursuance of my plan I sowed a core and several seeds of the early wilding pear, and the seeds of one Office Apple in Pot 17. and 2 horse Plum stones, and mingled apple and Pear seeds in Garden square South of Nursery and East of the gate—in a row close to the fence— E. Price Greenleaf was here this Evening.
13. IV. Tuesday.

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— I continue to write upon the Eulogy of Mr Madison; but not with sufficient application. Mr E. Price Greenleaf called here immediately after dinner, and I walked with him and my Son Charles over the hills to several of the Stone quarries upon which many of the Stone-cutters are at work— We visited three of those that are upon his father’s land— The Granite quarries are composed of hornblend which is black—of Quartz which is black—of Feldspar which isand of mica, which has an appearance like Isinglass, and seems to be Metallic— As the proportions of these ingredients differ the Stone is dark or light coloured, and the composition the general effect of which upon the eye, gives it a darkling blue tinge, is preferred above all others for the Walls of an house— So much so that much of the other Stone is unsaleable and will not pay for the expense of removing it— This is a mere fashion, and the public taste fluctuates from year to year so much with regard to the colour of the Stone, that the chances are a hundred to one that in the course of a very few years the Quincy Syenite, will be abandoned, and some other favourite material will take its place— The art of splitting and taking out the Stone is not yet fully understood.— In the third Chapter of the second Book of President Goguet’s Origin of the Laws Arts and Sciences, and of their progress among the antient Nations there is a very exact description of the manner in which they split up the rocks of Granite— He says it is practised in lower Normandy and he conjectures that it was used in antient Egypt. Goguet’s work was published in 1758—and he cites for authority the Memoirs of the Academy
of Sciences in 1751. Yet this art of splitting the granite was not practised or known here till about the year 1790 when the Quarries began to be worked—and the stone to be hammered. The granite from Chelmsford was for many years preferred to that from Quincy, and the latter was never much used till the railway was constructed in 1825 and 1826— It is now transported for building at New-York, New-Orleans, and the Havanna, and the workmen at the Quarries have nearly doubled in numbers within the last two years— Returning from the ledges we looked at Mr Price Greenleaf’s Nursery where many of his seedling trees are flourishing— He has several sorts of them which I have not—particularly the mountain ash, and the Tulip-tree, the seeds of which sown by me have not yet vegetated— He has the Quince also from the seed to which my soul is not suited— Joseph H. Adams dined with us and goes to-morrow for his station—
14. V. Wednesday.

A great and sudden change of weather— We thought this the hottest day of this year— At one O’Clock I went with Charles and bathed at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf— Swam about five minutes— Water clear and cold— The bath very refreshing. Charles went with William Spear this afternoon to the Quarries, and came to an explanation not very satisfactory with Dudley who makes use of his contract with me to work upon that which he had made with James Hall, whose rocks adjoin upon mine— He has failed in the performance of his engagements with me, but promises better for the future— My curiosity respecting the vegetation and growth of trees insensibly turns to entomology— I gathered a number of the worms which infest my trees with the intention to describe them in their various transformations, but the time fails me. Their varieties of form and appearance are wonderful— The two worms which I found a few days since upon the elm leaves, and which I would call the black Oak leaf worm, have gone into Chrysalis suspending themselves to the fibres of the leaves and to the side of the tumbler. The form of the grub is more like a crucified body than any thing else— The skin of the old caterpillar shrivelled up remains cast off at the side of the new one, and in the place of the former legs are 3 small shining particles like drops of silver or other metal— I planted 6 whole Office Apples in the Seminary front row, between two sickly seedling plum trees— The Gardener John Toohey gathered the dwarf tree Apples, to save them from being gathered by some one else; as the Bartlett Pears have been twice gathered— I planted also in Pot 13. 1. Bartlett Pear Core, and two Seeds. 15. Office Apple seeds and 2. Horse Plum Stones— I received this evening a Letter from the Mayor of Boston, Mr Armstrong, informing me that they had fixed upon Tuesday the 27th. of this month for the Eulogy on Mr Madison— The procession to form at half past two in the afternoon— They prefer the Odeon for the place; but if I choose, they will go the old South Meeting-House— I received also from Governor Everett with a pamphlet copy of his review of Nullification, and correspondence on the subject.
15. IV:30. Thursday

Charles and his wife, had engaged to go and spend the remainder of this week with Mr Brooks at Medford— She went into Boston with the Carriage— Mary and Elizabeth C. Adams went with her— I went with Charles in his Gig— I called first at the Mayor’s Office, to see and consult Mr Armstrong, but was informed he was gone to Hartford, and would not return till Saturday— First disappointment of the purpose of my visit— I spoke to the clerk of the Commons Council, and desired him to say to Mr Armstrong upon his return, that Tuesday the 27th. would suit me for the delivery of the Eulogy; but that I wished the time might be altered so that it should be eleven O’Clock in the Morning instead of 3— in the afternoon— I then went to Alexander H. Everett’s Office in the hope of seeing him; but he was not there, nor in the City— Second disappointment— I went to the Apartment of the Historical Society having
procured the key at the Savings Bank below— I examined the Library to see if I could find the debates of the Virginia Convention upon the revisal of their State Constitution; but it was not to be found— I did find however a Memorial and Remonstrance presented to the general Assembly of Virginia in 1785, in consequence of a Bill, brought into that Assembly for the Establishment of Religion by Law— This paper was written by Madison, and some notice was taken it in John S. Barbour’s Eulogy— I was very desirous of seeing it and found it unexpectedly here— I borrowed it and entered my name on the book as having taken it out— Then after a call at C. Brooks’s shop for a kettle boiler and pincers, I went to the Office of the Daily Advocate and conversed with Mr Hallett; and told him that although there might be an impropriety in my writing to him an electioneering Letter in favour of Alexander H. Everett, as a candidate for Election to Congress, for the 9th. District in the place of William Jackson who declines a re-election, I should yet be highly gratified if he should be elected— I said I had maintained doubts with regard to the question of his eligibility, on the ground of residence for a sufficient length of time in the district, but upon looking into the revised Statutes of the Commonwealth, I found there could be no objection on that score, and I referred him to the election of W. Eustis after his return from Holland, and to the second Election of John Bailey, after the first had been vacated by the senseless decision of the House of Representatives against him— Hallett gave me a copy of his 4th. of July Oration at Palmer— I went and obtained admission to the Odeon, and concluded to deliver the Eulogy upon James Madison, there— I then went and dined at the Revd. Dr Frothingham’s, at the invitation of my Son Charles’s wife— They and Mary also dined there— Charles and his wife after dinner went to Medford to pass the remainder of the week with Mr Brooks, and I returned with Mary and Elizabeth C. Adams home to Quincy— While I was gone there had been here as visitors Mr Thomas S. Mitchell, of South-Carolina heretofore a member of Congress, with a Mr and Mrs Forsyth, and another Gentleman and Lady from the same State.
16. IV:15. Friday.

I returned to the composition of the Eulogy upon James Madison, which although at its 100th. page is not yet finished— This morning I prepared a new exordium which will enable me to abridge the discourse by about one half. Mr Johnson the present agent of the Railway company was here, and showed me the plan of a new rail, for which they wish to purchase or to hire a small strip of my land— I told him I would go and inspect the place—that I should very cheerfully do any thing in my power for the accommodation of the company, though I had not found it practicable to agree with them concerning the land they had taken, and that which they wanted belonging to me; and that I should refer them for any arrangement which they might desire, to my Son Charles, for the adjustment of the terms— Mr Johnson mentioned that he had a fine fruit garden, especially well stocked with Plums; and said if it was not too late he would send me some white Gages from a tree so prolific that he had once received 49 dollars for the plums produced from it, sold at Boston market, besides a plentiful supply for the use of his own family. Mr Johnson has heard of my humours about fruit trees— I planted 1. Eperne Core 5 Porter Apple-seeds 3. Peach Stones 2. Horse Plum Stones, and some dry white currants in the Seminary front row, from the seedling Plum tree to the 1st. Elm— Wilson is repairing the Seminary fence, and Toohey is breaking up the lower garden ground— After dinner I took a walk round Mr. Daniel Greenleaf’s ground— Of the Oak trees of which he has a number, only one or two bear acorns, and they are not ripe— Neither were the berries of the horn beam; and I found only of the Apple-trees one the seeds of which were presently ripe and the fruit of that was bitter. I gathered
some of the seeds to sow, and call it the red wormwood— This evening I read in part, and Mary read the remainder of James Barbour’s Oration in honour of Madison.
17. IV. Saturday.

The Sun rose clear, and in about ten minutes went into a dark cloud; a symptom which I hold infallible of foul weather— This time however it portended not much of a storm— There was rain about the middle of the day; but not much— I resumed the attempt to finish the Eulogy of Madison, but without success— After changing the exordium I would adapt the concluding sentences to the introduction, and this is a task of no easy execution— I sowed 3. Porter Apple seeds, and 3. white sugar Pear seeds in Pot 4—where there are already one Nursery seedling Strawberry, and 2 Ash seeds— And wishing to make more accurately the experiment of planting whole Apples, I planted 7. whole Office Apples in a cross row, between two small seedling elms in the bed next the fence South and East of the Garden gate. The Apples at the two ends and that at the centre being entire, and two on each side of the centre cut into quarters— With several Porter Apple seeds 2 unripe horn beam seeds, and one Plum stone. None of which I expect will come up— Three Strawberry-Plants have come up from seeds sown by me last Summer in the Seminary, adjoining the gate— They thrive rapidly and have thrown out runners in all directions— I had the ground this day broken up, and the derivative plants fixed in radiated points from the centres to make them cover the whole bed— The three plants, transplanted from Pot 16. are also putting out runners— Charles and his wife returned this evening from their visit to Medford— He brought me sundry Peach stones and Pear seeds, with a present of black Hamburg and Sweet water grapes from Mr Brooks to my wife. Mr Johnson from the Railway also sent me a present of white Gage and Flushing Plums and of beautiful Dahlias to Mrs Adams.
18. V. Sunday

Heard Mr Lunt this morning, from John 20.29. “Jesus saith unto him, Thomas, because thou hast seen me, thou hast believed: blessed are they that have not seen, and yet have believed.” The discourse was upon the unreasonableness of disbelieving credible testimony, and the necessity of Faith— A doctrine to which Mr Lunt frequently returns— He said the words of the text were of a severe rebuke to Thomas upon his incredulity, and were deserved— He related the whole transaction recorded in the Chapter, and reviewed all the Circumstances, which should have induced implicit faith on the part of Thomas in the averment of his, associate Apostles—that they had seen Jesus— The whole Sermon was then a copious and ingenious argument for belief without seeing—or faith— Louisa C. Smith and Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us. Mr Lunt’s afternoon discourse, was from James 1.19. [“]Wherefore my beloved brethren, let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath”— A dissuasion from anger— The antithesis of swift and slow, as applied to hearing and speaking is impressive— The swiftness to hear implies not only an attentive ear, but an ardent impulse to go and seek the Speaker, and the transition from slowness of Speech to slowness of wrath, is an indirect admonition that wrath is the natural offspring of hasty speech— I read the first Sermon of the 9th. volume of Saurin, upon Perseverance; by which he means what is commonly called the Perseverance of the Saints— The text is from Hebrews 12.1. and there seemed to be something of the School Divinity in his treatment of the Subject— I should have preferred a Dissertation upon Perseverance, as a property of the human character, and a duty of Christian morality— He analyzes the text, and finds it divisible into three parts, exhibiting imperious duties,—bright examples, and wise precautions— But the composition is too artificial, and the transcendant importance of perseverance as a moral obligation, and its overruling influence to promote the success of all high enterprize
is not set forth in this discourse— Mr Lunt gave notice that the Revd: Mr Taylor of Boston, would deliver a Lecture on Temperance this Evening at 7. O’Clock at the Episcopal Church— I went with my Son Charles to hear it— The Lecture was a Sermon from Titus 2.11. For the grace of God that bringeth Salvation, hath appeared to all men, 12. Teaching us, that denying ungodliness and worldly lusts, we should live soberly, righteously, and godly in this present world— The discourse was delivered without notes, nearly two hours long, and full of repetitions; but well adapted to produce effect upon a teachable auditory, occasionally eloquent and sometimes pathetic— The Style was methodistical, and the creed trinitarian— The Ladies spent the Evening at Mr Edward Miller’s.
19. IV:30. Monday.

A man named Higgins, a Well-digger came out from Boston, with three workmen, and began digging for a Well on the Hill where Charles has determined to build a small dwelling House— William Spear, and my Tenant John J. Carr were there with a plough, and a yoke of Oxen, and began ploughing up the ground to dig the cellar— I went over upon the Hill, and saw them break ground for both the operations [symbols]— The Well is to be five and a half feet in diameter— The house 38 feet square. While I was there Mr Johnson from the Railway came to my house and I returned: Charles agreed to go with him to the ground next Thursday; and I referred Mr Johnson to him for any arrangements to be made— The day was one of the warmest of the year. The sky clear as crystal— I had seen before daylight, Jupiter and Venus in conjunction, with scarcely more than the width of the Suns disk between them— The prospect from the Hill is exquisitely beautiful— Mary, and Charles’s wife, with the three little girls spent the afternoon at Mrs Edward Miller’s— Elizabeth C. Adams came home with them; to pass the Night here— With Charles I bathed and swam ten minutes at Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf, between 5 and 6 in the afternoon— Mr Beale and his daughter were here in the afternoon-evening— He has been quite unwell— I finished my first draft of the Eulogy upon Mr Madison, and have now the more difficult task of revising and pruning— I measured the tall Apple seedling opposite the St. Michael Pear tree adjoining the Summer house cellar— Seed Sown October 1833— Growth of 1834. 18 inches—of 1835 38 inches; of this Season 21 inches. The tree is now 6 feet 5 inches high— This to me is a phenomenon— I have sown many thousands of Apple Seeds, and have observed many hundreds of Seedlings— Never one to compare with this— I have at least 100 Seedlings of this year— The tallest is not more than 5 inches high— I filled Pot 18 with 4. Amory Pear Seeds 4. Porter Apple-seeds a Holland Peach Stone, and Flushing Plum Stone. And sowed mingled Office and red wormwood Apple seeds, 2 Peach Stones and 2. Flushing Plum Stones, in front Seminary row, from first Elm to young fir tree—with four white sugar Pear Cores— I put down Stakes in the Pots inscribed with the Seeds sown in them.
20. IV:15. Tuesday

Mary, with her daughter Georgiana Frances and Elizabeth C. Adams went to Medford to pass the remainder of the week with Mrs John Angier— Charles went with them to Boston, but returned to dine— The heat of the weather was so intense that I could not give much labour either to the Garden, or to the chamber— Great part of the morning was occupied in a review of the Eulogy, for the purpose of abridging it but without effecting much— Henry Hardwick was here enquiring for the deed of Saltmarsh land which I am to execute to him, but it was not ready— I answered the letter last received from the Mayor respecting the time and place for the delivery of the Eulogy upon James Madison; and I answered the invitation from the Committee of
Arrangements for the centennial celebration of the incorporation and Settlement of the town of Dedham, which is to take place to-morrow— I declined the invitation; for which my engagements do not allow me time— After dinner I went over upon the Hill, where the workmen, employed to dig Charles’s Well and cellar were employed— Charles and E. Price Greenleaf were there— The well-diggers had penetrated about fourteen feet deep, without yet meeting water— We walked over to Colburn’s ledge where we found the men at work, but the stone is not so promising as it was—
21. IV:15. Wednesday— Autumnal Equinox.

I have much more difficulty in abridging the Eulogy for delivery than I had in writing it— There is a chain of narrative and of reflection from which I cannot separate a single link without breaking its continuity, and making it a mere fragment— The agency of Mr Madison, as a member of the Confederation Congress, of the Legislature of Virginia, and of the Conventions of Annapolis and of Philadelphia, in preparing the Constitution of the United States—his exertions in obtaining its adoption by the People, as one of the writers of the Federalist, and as a member of the Virginia Convention— His controversy with Hamilton under the signature of Helvidius His operations in the Virginia Legislature, relating to the Alien and Sedition Laws. His career as Secretary of State under Mr Jefferson, succeeded by his own Administration as Secretary President of the United-States, present a mass of materials so various in its character and so copious of reflection, that it is scarcely possible to reduce them within the limits of a deliverable discourse— They are subjects too, exceedingly difficult and dangerous to discuss, and in the treatment of which it will be impossible to escape bitter censure— I was somewhat interrupted in my revisal this day, by the visits of Mr And Mrs. James H. Foster, and afterwards of Mr And Mrs Cruft from Boston— I walked with Mr Foster over to the Hill where Charles’s workmen are engaged— Mrs Cruft is very much out of health, and has the appearance of an irretrievable consumption— The weather this day was cool but my plantations are suspended by the drought which is very great— I planted one whole Flushing Plum at the corner of the Garden Nursery Gate Bed, South of the fence and East of the Gate, with an inscribed stake to mark the spot.
22. IV:15. Thursday.

My Grandson John Quincy’s birth-day— He is three years of age, and three feet high— His Sister Louisa Catherine, five years one month and ten days old is 3 feet 4 inches high, and my Grand-daughter Mary Louisa 7 years 9 months and 20 days old is 3. feet 10.— John Quincy was unwell last Night, and slightly indisposed this day, but better towards night— Mrs Glover came here with a Subscription book for the Quincy charitable Society; consisting chiefly of Ladies— I requested to have the name of my wife entered upon the Book as a member for Life. Mrs T. B. Adams and Louisa C. Smith dined and spent the Evening with us— I have suspended my plantations during the excessive drought—waiting for rain to moisten the ground— This afternoon I walked with Charles over the Hill, and saw his workmen digging the well, and blowing the rocks for Stones to lay his cellar— They dig about six feet deep every day, and have yet come only to lumps of moist clay—no water and little worthy of remark except some curious composition of stones which Charles supposes to be iron— We went over to the Quarries and found Dutton with three men at work upon Colburn’s ledge— There they have taken out several blocks of the very best stone but have now come to that which is worth nothing in the same rock— We also foundHardwick, Son of Charles
Hardwick, attempting to split off a block from a very high rock, on my land adjoining upon that of Isaac Bass— Hardwick had applied to my Son Charles for permission to split off this block with a view to ascertain the quality of the Stone, and if it should turn out good, to hire the ledge—but the rock was too stubborn and too deeply stained— He proposed to try a blast of gunpowder upon it, to-morrow morning. I gathered sundry red oak Acorns fallen from the very large tree which I have hitherto taken for a black Oak, and from which I have never before found acorns to ascertain its kind— Also four Shagbark Nuts, one rock ruby apple, one red wedge apple, and several ash-seeds— I devoted much of the Evening to writing
23. III:30. Friday

Change of weather to a Northeast wind, with a threatened equinoctial gale, not realized—my own laborious task at this time is to abridge my Eulogy so as to bring it within the compass of two hours delivery— I was under the necessity of writing this morning a new paragraph relating to incidents in the Life of Mr Madison, which I had not before noticed. It refers to his agency in carrying through the Virginia Legislature the Bill for the Establishment of Religious Freedom, and in the revisal of the Code of Statute Laws. Part of the day was occupied in copying over what I had written— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. I had risen so early that after dinner I was unable to read or write— I walked over the hill, where Charles’s well diggers are delving, and at the depth of 28 feet have not yet reached water— The earth which they bring up is a blueish clay almost as hard as brick—and comes up moist but not wet— The Ladies spend the afternoon with the Children; and the Evening without them at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— Mr Price Greenleaf called here early in the Evening, and Charles walked with him to Mrs Adams’s— I made a very short Evening at home. I found all the red Oak Acorns that I had gathered yesterday under the giant tree floated upon water, except four, which I planted in a cross row at the Eastern end of the Seminary—and next to it another cross row of white sugar pears and Cores—and I finished a row next to the Nursery fence, in the Garden East of the gate.
24. IV:45. Saturday

I rose this morning nearly an hour later than my standard time, as I had risen yesterday half an hour earlier. Charles’s wife went to Boston this morning, and in the afternoon returned with Mary, her daughter Fanny, and Elizabeth C. Adams from their visit to Mrs John Angier at Medford. They were all slightly indisposed; as I have been all this day— Mr and Mrs Turnbull, with their Sisters Mrs Samuel Lawrence, and Miss Turnbull were here, with Mrs Turnbull’s daughter Mary, a child six years of age. They came chiefly to see Mary an old acquaintance and friend of Mrs Turnbull formerly Jane Ramsay— William Turnbull is a Captain by Brevet of the topographical engineers— His wife has been some weeks at Boston, upon a visit to his Sister Mrs Lawrence, and he has just come from Washington to take her home— I found my gardener had this morning torn up, and cast away a fine young elm, about ten feet high, which has been growing unobserved five or six years close to the dwarf Apple-tree— I made him set the Elm out again, in place of one of the English Oaks transplanted last autumn, east of the Nursery eastern fence; but I fear he has killed the tree, by cutting off the taproot too short— I planted 12 whole Office Apples, in a second South of the Nursery fence and East of the gate: in a line with a seedling Apple and Cherry tree of the present year with peach and plum stones and dried currants— In this bed, where my plantations of last year almost entirely failed, there are yet of seedlings of the present
present year 3 peaches 3 apples, 2 Walnuts, 1 Cherry and at least ten self-planted elms— I note them only to mark how many of them will be alive next Summer— After dinner I walked round Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s lands and gathered Tupelo berries; white birch seeds—red wormwood and red sherbet wilding Apple seeds and one red Oak acorn— I went over the hill, where two men were blowing up with gunpowder a pudding stone rock, to be used for stoning Charles’s cellar—but it was too intractable as are all that kind of rocks— The three Irishmen who have been digging his Well, had left their work, and gone into Boston— They have in the week dug 34 feet deep without yet striking a Spring— Yet as they deepened there are drops of water oozing from the sides of the ground through which they passed, and I found the bottom nearly covered with water.— I have been somewhat indisposed all this day, and was quite unwell this Evening, with the prospect of a bad night.
25. V.45 Sunday

A night almost sleepless, in which I was twice roused from my bed, was followed by a languid an indolent morning. It was near Sun rise when I rose, and I had neither voice to read, nor hand to write— I was obliged to rely entirely upon my Son Charles for the copy of my Eulogy which I am to deliver, and with a painful uncertainty whether I shall be able to speak it at all— Heard Mr Charles Brooks of Hingham, in the morning from Matthew 9.29. “Then touched he their eyes, saying, according to your faith, be it unto you.” A Sermon upon Faith— Mr Brooks dined with us; and while we were at dinner I mentioned to him that Mr Lunt had given us last Sunday morning upon the same Subject of Faith, and repeated his text— Mr Brooks said if he had known that, he should have chosen another Sermon for this morning; that he had a second part of the same discourse, which he had intended to give this afternoon; but he should now select another.— Accordingly his afternoon Sermon was from Isaiah 54.13. “And all thy children shall be taught of the Lord; and great shall be the peace of thy children.” It was upon the hackneyed subject of education, and contained a review of Cousin’s account of the German system of education— I should have preferred the second part of the discourse upon Faith— Mr Brooks baptised a child by the name of Frances Lincoln—(Souther) and a note was read requesting prayers for Ebenezer Crane, dangerously sick— I read the second Sermon of the 9th. Vol. of Saurin, upon the examples of the Saints— It is the second part of the Discourse upon Perseverance, and with the same text— Mary was so unwell as to be confined the whole day after breakfast to her chamber— I am not a little discouraged; considering the exceeding precariousness of my voice, and with a strong misgiving that I ought not to have undertaken this task.
26. IV:15. Monday

I had a more tranquil night, and felt myself recovering from my indisposition, but on attempting to read part of my Eulogy this Morning I found my voice almost extinguished and could not speak to be heard at fifty feet distance— The night was cold; and my thermo this morning before Sunrise marked in the open air only 40 degrees of Fahrenheit. Wind a cold gale from the Northwest; but the Sun rose in all his sublimity— My indisposition was not entirely removed, and a second attempt after breakfast to read my Eulogy was again unsuccessful, though with a partial recovery of my voice— I confined my self almost all the morning to my chamber revising again and still abridging the second copy of my Eulogy, for which I have been obliged to the assistance of my Son Charles. After dinner William Spear was here, and said that Peter Turner had spoken to him of a lot of woodland adjoining some of mine, which he proposed to sell, and has asked
him to mention it to me, and enquire whether I would be disposed to purchase it. I agreed to go with Mr Spear and look at it on Thursday morning. I walked with Charles over the hill where his well diggers are still delving for water; and then to the old Trask lot where Dutton is about commencing the search for a new ledge of blue granite— Hardwick’s experiment on the high rock has failed— He has blown off and split up from it two or three blocks weighing several Tons, but it proves to be not of the choice colour, nor does it split well— Colburn’s ledge succeeds better: but yet with some diversity in the colour of the Stone
27. IV:15. Tuesday— Boston— Eulogy on James Madison—

I went this morning to Boston with my Son Charles, who took with him his daughter, Louisa-Catherine— We stopped at his house till half-past nine, when he went with me to the house of Mr Armstrong, the Mayor of the City— With him I went to the State-House where the procession was to form at ten— In the Senate chamber I met Mr T. S. Mitchell of South-Carolina, Mr Berrien of Georgia, and Coll. King of that State, Genl. John P. Van Ness of the City of Washington—Dr Waterhouse—Alexr. H. Everett, and his Brother Edward Everett the Governor of the Commonwealth—Mr Silsbee of Salem, Mr Abbott Lawrence, and Mr Stephen C. Phillips, members of the House of Representatives, and some others— It was half past ten when the procession marched from the State House preceded by several military companies of the City— It went down and up State Streets, to the antient Federal Street Theatre now called the Odeon— Where after a voluntary upon the Organ by G. J. Webb— A prayer by Dr Charles Lowell— An Ode by the Choir of the Boston Academy of Music—the Poetry by Park Benjamin—the Music by G. J. Webb. I delivered an Eulogy upon the life and character of James Madison— Two hours and a half were occupied in the delivery, and yet I omitted much of the abridgement of my discourse in the copy made chiefly by my Son— The House was crowded to the utmost of its capacity— I had undertaken this task with a most painful anxiety and fear that I might be disabled from performing it altogether— An anxiety much sharpened by the illness which for the last three days had almost extinguished my voice— I did get through, but with extreme difficulty; with frequent imperfections of delivery; without being able to raise my voice to be heard throughout the house, and with entire conviction, that I must never again engage to address such an auditory, on a day fixed before hand—or indeed upon any day or any occasion— Forty three years and more have passed away since I first spoke to a crowded audience in Boston— My voice is now gone— My eyes are in no better condition— The day was uncommonly darkened with clouds, and threatened rain the whole morning—there was a heavy shower while I was speaking; and the house being lighted only by Sky-lights from above, there were parts of the time when I found it impossible to read, and was obliged to pass over towards the end or repeat from memory. The delivery was accordingly bad, and I was under much agitation with the fear that I should be forced to break off in the midst of my Address, and declare my inability to proceed— There was however an uninterrupted and fixed attention of the auditory throughout the whole Time; occasional slight cheerings of applause, and at the close, a full, and long continued manifestation of satisfaction— Mr Abbott Lawrence, and Mr Stephen C. Phillips were the first to greet me, with their hands, and the expression of warm and entire approbation— They were followed by my old friends John Welles, Judge Davis, President Quincy, and several others, among whom was Dr. Lowell who had made the prayer. A Hymn was then sung by the Choir, and
after the benediction by Dr Lowell, the procession was dismissed by Mr Pollard, the Clerk of the City Government— I walked home with Mr Armstrong the Mayor who had invited me, and my Son to a family dinner, which I had accepted. Dr Lowell Miss Walker, a Sister of Mrs Armstrong, and two young men, named Homer, and Bigelow, who had been among the Marshals of the procession, were the company at the dinner party which was social, and very agreeable— After dinner I returned with Charles to his house, and then with him and his little daughter to Quincy, where we found our own families not risen from the dinner table— They had waited for us, till past six O’Clock; as we had intended to return to dine.— We had dissuaded the Ladies from going, to encounter the agitations of so great a crowd, and I rejoiced that they were not there— I closed the day with Gratitude to Heaven, for my deliverance from this trial, and with a firm determination never again to expose myself to the same hazards
28. V:30. Wednesday.

I indulged myself this morning with a longer term of repose than is my usual custom, and after the tension and anxiety of preparation for the last two months gave myself a holiday for idleness. The day was so cold that I could write but little in my cham- and I spent part of the time before dinner in my garden, and after dinner in my Seminary, digging for exercise and sowing seeds for future vegetation alteri seculo although these places have lost the attraction of Spring and Summer— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— I planted a row of dwarf Apple seeds from the young Baldwin Apple-tree next the road to the Summer house cellar, and a row of Dexter Apple Seeds in front of the Seminary fence, from the fir tree to the second elm. My purpose is if life be allowed me to observe for two or three Summers the difference of growth of the seedlings from these and other varieties of the Apple-tree— I have several seedlings of this year, I believe from the seeds of the dwarf tree— They are living and appear to be healthy, but are not one inch high; while the stem of the tall seedling opposite the Summer house cellar has grown 21 inches this Session: one of the shoots from a bud inserted in August 1834 and which first opened a year afterwards has grown full three feet this Season— This difference of growth in a Season, from one inch to three feet, in varieties of the same fruit is the most remarkable phenomenon that has struck my observation— I would gladly continue and give precision and variety to my experiments till they should end in some useful result; but I have not the time— Two young men from Boston were here this afternoon; one of them named Glover who enquired, if I would sell my Estate at the Corner of Tremont and Boylston Streets, which I said I would, but that having no particular desire to sell I should ask a high price for it. He enquired what price; and I said I should be glad to enquire what it would be thought worth by others— That I had given twenty-thousand dollars for it more than thirty years ago, and I asked what he would estimate as its value himself—he was not willing to say— I told him I would in the course of two or three days fix a price which I would take for it, and send him word by my Son; at whose office he said he would call— I asked Charles what he thought would be a reasonable price to fix upon it; he said thirty thousand dollars, and I
authorised him to name that to Mr Glover as my price— Mary, and Charles with his wife, went and passed the Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s.
29. V:30. Thursday.

I have usually abstained from kindling a fire in my chamber till the first of October, but was constrained by the weather of this day to anticipate that operation. There was a cold, but very moderate rain which continued with scarcely any intermission the whole day— I attempted two or three times to visit my garden and nursery; but each time was driven back by the rain into my chamber— Louisa C. Smith came here to dine, and is to remain here this Night, and the Ladies have had here all the week, Mrs Richards, a Mantua maker from Boston, working for them, and for winter clothing for the children— I read the Article from the North American review upon nullification, sent to me by Mr Edward Everett, and written by him in 1830— I read also the Letters from Mr Madison to him, upon the subject, of the same dates— I have undertaken to mark in very explicit terms, the difference between the opinions, the purposes, and the conduct of Mr Madison and Mr Jefferson with reference to the alien and the Sedition acts— They were very remarkably different. I foresee that this may engage me in a controversy with the Jeffersonian School of the South; and that it will be specially unpalateable in Virginia— There are many considerations which make this exceedingly hazardous at my time of life, but after long deliberation, I have concluded that there is a duty for me to perform—a duty to the memory of my father—a duty to the character of the People of New-England— A duty to truth and Justice— If controversy is made, I shall have an arduous and probably a very unthankful task to perform, and may sink under it; but I will defend my father’s fame; I will vindicate the New-England character, and I will expose some of the fraudulent pretences of Slave-holding democracy— I pray for temper, moderation, firmness and self-controul; and above all for a pure and honest purpose—and if it so please Heaven, for success.
30. V:30. Friday.

Fahrenheit 32— The weather cleared up in the Night, and the Sun rose majestically— It was too cold for me to be able to write in my chamber without a fire; and I had various reasons for abstaining from making it— I walked before breakfast round, by the meeting house, and the Scotch pond; and over the hills back to my house— After breakfast deacon Spear came with his horse and waggon— I went with him and my Son, and we took up Peter Turner, to the lot of woodland adjoining upon mine and upon Owen’s field—the lot which Peter Turner had to sell— We examined it, as far as I thought necessary, and I agreed to give him for it at the rate of fifty dollars an acre— He promised to send for Mr Humphrey very shortly to have it surveyed and a plan of it made, and to furnish me a perfect title— This afternoon Mr Isaac Waters, a member of the Common Council of Boston, and John H. Eastburn the City Printer came out and brought a Letter from Mr Armstrong the Mayor, enclosing the concurrent vote of the board of Alderman, and the Common Council, requesting a copy of my Eulogy, for the press— I told Mr Eastburn, that as in the case of the Eulogy upon James Monroe, I should probably print much more than was delivered; and would revise the manuscripts so as to send them to him to-morrow morning. He promised to send me out by the mail a proof sheet every morning; and that he would print the work in a Style, equal to that of the Eulogy upon Mr Monroe— He also promised to apply to Dr Lowell, for a copy of his prayer—and for copies of the Ode and Hymn that were performed— Louisa C. Smith returned this Evening to Mrs T. B. Adams’s—and Mary and Charles and his wife, went there to an evening party— E. Price Greenleaf was here a few minutes, and went
hence also to Mrs T. B. Adams’s— I was engaged all the Evening in revising my manuscripts for the Press— I extract about 20 pages of my first manuscript, and yet omit nearly as much as I retain— The Eulogy as printed will be shorter than that upon La Fayette; and even than that upon Mr Monroe— I did not finish my revisal.

Day— The distribution of time varies little from that of the preceding months; but as the rising of the Sun grows later, and the darkness of the morning, and the chills of autumn increase, my rising hour falls into arrears, and I can no longer write with comfort before breakfast— I am greatly relieved from the labour of writing for the Eulogy, and feel like a Schoolboy released from recitation— But I have great arrears of correspondence to redeem—and must soon think of departure with my family for the winter at Washington.
